A Dedekind domain is an integral domain in which the theorem on unique prime factorization holds for ideals. It is a nonzero ring without nontrivial zero divisors, and Dedekind's theorem on unique prime factorization for ideals is applicable.
For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the sum $\mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\{a+b ; a \in \mathfrak{a}, b \in \mathfrak{b}\}$.
Does the concept of a/an Dedekind Domain need to be defined for a definition of a/an Sum of Ideals to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of a Sum of Ideals is defined for any two ideals in a ring R, where the sum is the set of all possible sums of elements from each ideal. This definition requires only the structure of a ring and the concept of ideals within that ring. It does not specifically require the ring to be a Dedekind domain or any other specific type of ring, just that it supports the operations and properties of ideals.\n\nOn the other hand, a Dedekind Domain is a specific type of integral domain with unique properties regarding the factorization of ideals. While the properties of a Dedekind Domain can influence the behavior and properties of ideals within it, the basic definition and concept of the Sum of Ideals do not inherently require the ring to be a Dedekind Domain. The Sum of Ideals can be defined and understood in any ring that supports the basic concept of ideals, regardless of whether it has the additional properties of a Dedekind Domain.
